title: NEPA Clean Energy Analysis: Progress Report
text:
This report summarizes progress on analyzing NEPA (National Environmental Policy Act) compliance data for clean energy projects. We present findings from two deliverables:

Deliverable 1: Characterizing the clean energy project landscape by technology, lead agency, and geographic location
Deliverable 3: Analyzing NEPA process types (CE, EA, EIS) across energy classifications







Data Scope



Analysis covers 26,000+ clean energy projects extracted from the NEPA database, classified using energy technology tags (solar, wind, transmission, storage, geothermal, hydropower, nuclear, hydrogen, and efficiency/conservation).

title: NEPA Clean Energy Analysis: Progress Report
text:
Technology Distribution
How are clean energy projects distributed across technology types?





Figure 1: Distribution of clean energy projects by technology type. Projects may have multiple technology tags.










Key Finding: Technology



Transmission and solar dominate the clean energy NEPA landscape. Transmission projects comprise the largest share, reflecting the infrastructure buildout required to connect renewable generation to load centers. Solar’s prominence aligns with its rapid deployment growth over the analysis period.

Figure 3: NEPA process type composition by lead department










Key Finding: Agency



DOE dominates clean energy NEPA reviews (81% of projects), followed by Interior (17%). Notably, DOE processes the vast majority through Categorical Exclusions (96%), while Interior shows more variation across process types. This concentration suggests DOE’s loan programs and grid modernization initiatives drive most federal clean energy review activity.

County-Level Distribution





Figure 5: Clean energy projects by county. Note: County data available for approximately 47% of projects.






Process Type by Location





Figure 6: Clean energy project locations by NEPA process type. Points placed at county centroids; size indicates project count.










Key Finding: Geography



Clean energy projects concentrate in the Western states and Southeast nuclear corridor. South Carolina leads (driven by Savannah River Site activity), followed by Washington, California, and Idaho. The county-level map reveals clustering around major federal facilities and high-resource renewable areas (desert Southwest for solar, Great Plains for wind).

title: NEPA Clean Energy Analysis: Progress Report
text:
Process Types by Energy Classification
How do NEPA review processes differ across energy types (Clean, Fossil, Other)?





Figure 7: NEPA process type by energy classification









Figure 8: Composition of NEPA process types within each energy classification










Key Finding: Process Type



Clean energy projects use Categorical Exclusions at higher rates than fossil fuel projects. This likely reflects:

Smaller project footprints (rooftop solar, efficiency upgrades)
DOE’s programmatic CEs for loan guarantee activities
Routine transmission maintenance and upgrades

Fossil projects show higher EA/EIS rates, consistent with larger environmental footprints requiring more detailed review.

title: NEPA Clean Energy Analysis: Progress Report
text:
In Progress

Generation Capacity Analysis






Data Limitation: Capacity Variables



Preliminary exploration of generation capacity fields reveals substantial missing data. We are evaluating:

Option A: Subset analysis using only records with capacity data (reduced sample size)
Option B: Imputation strategies using project type and technology proxies
Option C: Supplementing with external capacity databases (EIA-860)

Recommendation: We suggest discussing the tradeoffs at Thursday’s meeting to determine the preferred approach.




Timeline Analysis
NEPA review duration analysis requires:

Parsing decision dates from document records
Handling projects with multiple decision documents
Defining appropriate start/end date conventions

Current status: Data cleaning underway; preliminary results expected next cycle.

title: Multi-Label Project Tagging: Visualization Guidance
text:
This is a classic multi-label classification / tagging problem, and you’re right to be uneasy with a simple frequency table—those almost always confuse non-technical clients.
Below, I’ll lay out conceptually distinct visualization options, ordered from most client-friendly to most analytically rich, with notes on when to use each and what question it answers. I’ll also flag which ones avoid the “double-counting” problem.



Your client is essentially asking:

“Which projects touch any of these energy-relevant domains, and how often do those domains appear—alone or together?”

This suggests three analytical lenses:

Presence / coverage – Does a project have this tag at all?

Overlap – Which tags co-occur?

Dominant identity – What is the primary energy category, if any?

Different visuals answer different lenses.




What it shows:

For each target tag: % of projects that include it at least once

No double-counting confusion

How it works:

Convert multi-valued tags into binary indicators: ```r has_solar = TRUE/FALSE has_transmission = TRUE/FALSE

Visualize as: Bar chart Dot plot Table with % of total projects Example framing: “X% of clean energy projects involve utilities; Y% involve solar; Z% involve electricity transmission.” Pros: ✅ Very easy to explain ✅ No inflation of counts ✅ Directly answers client’s “which ones have these tags?” question Cons: ❌ Loses information about overlap and combinations Recommendation: This should almost certainly be your first figure. 3. Option 2: Single vs Multi-Tag Composition (Diagnostic View) What it shows: How complex projects are: 1 tag 2 tags 3+ tags Visuals: Simple bar chart or stacked bar Why it helps: Explains why counts exceed the number of projects Justifies more complex visuals Client framing: “About 40% of projects span multiple policy domains, so categories are not mutually exclusive.” Often useful as a methods slide, not a headline result. 4. Option 3: UpSet Plot (Best for Overlap Patterns) What it shows: Which combinations of tags appear together How common each combination is Example combinations: Solar + Utilities Wind (onshore) + Transmission CCS + Pipelines + Utilities Why UpSet works better than Venn diagrams: Scales to many categories Emphasizes observed combinations, not theoretical ones When to use: If the client asks: “What types of projects tend to involve utilities or transmission?” Pros: ✅ Handles many tags ✅ Makes co-occurrence explicit ✅ No double-counting confusion Cons: ❌ Requires a brief explanation ❌ Less familiar to non-technical audiences Great as a second- or third-level figure. 5. Option 4: Co-Occurrence Heatmap (Relationship-Focused) What it shows: A matrix: Rows = tags Columns = tags Cell value = number or % of projects containing both Interpretation: Darker cells = strong association Diagonal = total presence Example insight: “Electricity transmission almost always appears with utilities, but rarely with biomass.” Pros: ✅ Very compact ✅ Reveals structural relationships ✅ Good for technical appendices Cons: ❌ Less intuitive ❌ Can feel abstract to clients Best used after simpler summaries. 6. Option 5: Primary Tag Assignment (Decision-Oriented) What it shows: Assign each project one primary category, based on: Priority rules (e.g., generation > transmission > utilities) First-listed tag Capacity-weighted tag Visualize as a standard mutually exclusive bar chart Why clients like this: Answers: “If I had to put each project in one bucket, where would it go?” Risks (must be documented): ⚠️ Subjective rules ⚠️ Masks hybrid projects Fine if framed explicitly as a simplification. 7. Option 6: Two-Level Hierarchy (Energy Type × Infrastructure) What it shows: Projects broken into: Energy type (solar, wind, nuclear, CCS, etc.) Infrastructure involvement (utilities, transmission, both, neither) Visuals: Faceted bar charts Stacked bars Sankey diagram (if careful) Why this is powerful: Bridges substantive energy questions and regulatory/infrastructure implications Example insight: “Most wind projects also involve transmission, while solar projects often involve utilities but not new transmission.” 8. Option 7: Client-Safe Table Design (When Tables Are Unavoidable) Instead of raw counts: Tag % of Projects with Tag Avg. Tags per Project Solar 42% 2.1 Utilities 58% 2.8 This reframes multiplicity as context, not confusion. 9. Recommended Sequence (Practical) Binary presence bar chart – headline figure Single vs multi-tag distribution – methods clarity UpSet plot of top 10 combinations – structure Co-occurrence heatmap – appendix or technical section Why this combination works: Avoids misleading totals Respects project complexity Defensible in peer review Legible to non-technical clients

CATEGORICAL EXCLUSION REVIEW AND APPROVAL
A. Background

Lease/Serial/Case File No.: Grazing Case File Number 2506717

On May 6, 2016, the Lewistown BLM Field Office received completed transfer of grazing
preference application forms (4130-1, 4130-1a, 4130-1b and 4120-8) from Joseph C. Bodner
with a Deed showing control of the base property. The BLM determined that the applicant
meets the qualifications to hold a grazing permit (43 CFR §4110.1) and were deemed to have a
satisfactory performance record.

The proposed action is to approve the 67 AUM transfer of grazing preference in the Nebel
Coulee (#09665) Allotment from Conrad S. Bodner to Joseph C. Bodner and to issue a new
grazing lease.

The current 10 year term grazing lease expires on February 28, 2019. The renewed lease offered
to the applicant as a result of this grazing preference transfer will have the same terms and
conditions as the expiring lease and will be issued for term of 10 years effective March 1, 2017
and expire February 28, 2027. The renewed lease will be issued in accordance with Section
402(c)(2) of the Federal Land Policy Management Act (FLPMA) as amended by Public Law No.
113-291. Leases issued in accordance with Section 402(c)(2) of the FLPMA as amended by
Public Law No. 113-291 are not protestable or appealable under the processes described in 43
CFR §4160 and 43 CFR §4.470 et seq[1]. The following statement will be included in the cover
letter transmitting the grazing lease issued to continue the terms and conditions of the terminated
lease and the newly offered lease in accordance with the FLPMA Section 402(c)(2). This
language will also be included in the lease for tracking purposes but is not a term and condition
of the lease:

“This permit or lease is issued under the authority of Section 402(c)(2) of FLPMA, 1976 as
amended, and contains the same terms and conditions as the previous permit or lease. This
permit or lease may be cancelled, suspended, or modified, in whole or in part to meet the
requirements of applicable laws and regulations."

The terms and conditions (kind and number of livestock, period of use, area to be used, and

Ruby 1819-16H Well Pad

1.1 LOCATION AND DESCRIPTION OF THE PROPOSED ACTION:
EOG Resources Incorporated (EOG) proposes to drill one horizontal oil and gas well, the Ruby
1819-16H, with the following surface location:

Sixth Principal Meridian, Wyoming
T. 40 N., R. 72 W.,
sec. 18, NE1/4NW1/4.

EOG proposes to construct a drilling pad of approximately 510 x 710 feet, and a facilities pad of
approximately 600 x 510 feet. Additional acreage for cut/fill slopes and construction are within a
fenced boundary. EOG also proposes to construct and maintain approximately 130 feet (0.024
mile) of new access road with a running width of 20 feet and a maximum width of 60 feet (0.18
acres) needed for construction (Table 1). The well pad construction activities would occur on
private surface estate over off-lease Federal minerals, with horizontal legs producing from
Federal, and/or state or fee minerals. (Fee-Fee-Fed); while the road construction activities would
occur on private surface. The horizontal legs would produce from Federal oil and gas leases
WYW152109 and WYW144682 and WYW153117.

The water for drilling and completion operations would be pumped to the proposed location from
the Dilts 1-20 Water Pits located at T. 40 N, R. 72 W, sec. 20, SESW, Converse County,
Wyoming through a temporary flat line placed in the barrow ditch of existing and proposed
access road. If the well were to be productive, facilities would be built on the proposed Ruby
1819-16H facilities pad. Within six months of well completion, interim reclamation would be
performed on the well pad and access road if the proposed well on the location is productive.

If the well is not productive, it would be plugged, and all disturbance associated with this well
would be reclaimed to near natural, or landowner preferred conditions.

For more details on project area access, design features, construction practices, affected surface
owners and details regarding reclamation, refer to the Application for Permit to Drill (APDs).

A class III cultural resource inventory for the proposed well location and access road indicates
that no eligible cultural resources would be adversely affected by the proposed action. However,
due to Fee-Fee-Fed classification, all recommended mitigation measures for wildlife are based
on a GIS desktop review of all available data. In instances where a wildlife resource is not
represented or discounted with GIS data, the wildlife biologist has recommended all mitigation
measures for all wildlife resources that could potentially occur in the area.

The proposed action is not located within 2 miles of an occupied sage-grouse lek and is located
outside designated Priority Habitat Management Area (PHMA) (aka Core Area).

This categorical exclusion (CX) tiers to and incorporates by reference the information and
analysis contained in the Converse County Oil and Gas Project Final Environmental Impact

Casper, Wyoming 82604-2968

Introductory Section
EOG Resources Incorporated (EOG) is proposing the Ruby 1819-16H horizontal oil and gas well
allowing construction, drilling, completion, production, and reclamation of the well on a new
well pad on private surface estate over off-lease Federal minerals.
•
The proposed well, Ruby 1819-16H, will be drilled on the new Mary Draw 18 NENW
Pad.

Mitigation Measures
A list of Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Recommended Mitigation Measures (RMMs) and
Conditions of Approval (COAs)are attached to this decision and should be implemented and
followed with the acceptance of the Approved Application for Permit to Drill for the Ruby 1819-
16H horizontal oil and gas well.

The environmental protection measures identified by the operator in the drilling plans are
considered by the BLM to be applicant-committed Best Management Practices (BMPs) and are
required to be implemented and followed in the same manner as COAs accompanying this
decision.

Authorities
Statutory authorities for this decision are contained in the Minerals Leasing Act of 1920, as
amended, and supplemented (30 U.S.C. 181 et seq.).

Plan Conformance and Consistency
Pursuant to 40 CFR 1508.28 and 1502.21, this categorical exclusion (CX) tiers to and
incorporates by reference the information and analysis contained in the Approved Resource
Management Plan and Final Environmental Impact Statement for the Casper Field Office, the
Record of Decision and Approved Resource Management Plan (Casper RMP) approved on
December 7, 2007, as amended. The proposed action is in conformance with the Casper RMP
decisions, goals, and objectives.

Public Involvement
The proposed action forms 3160-3 were posted at the Casper Field Office on 4/21/2021. Per
Onshore Order No. 1 E.1, “The BLM and the Federal Surface Managing Agency, if other than
the BLM, must provide at least 30 days public notice before the BLM may approve an
Application for Permit to Drill (APD) or Master Development Plan on a Federal oil and gas
lease. The posting is for informational purposes only and is not an appealable decision. The
purpose of the posting is to give any interested party notification that a Federal approval of
mineral operations has been requested.” Due to the location and routine nature of the project,
external scoping beyond the affected parties was not performed. The BLM Casper Field Office
(CFO) interdisciplinary team (IDT) conducted internal scoping by reviewing the proposal, its
location and a resource (issue) list to identify potentially affected resources, land uses, resource
issues, regulations and site-specific circumstances. The IDT provided input relative to potential
impacts to various resources. This input was used to guide the scope and analysis for this CX.
The proposed action was posted to the ePlanning National Register on May 13, 2021.

The BLM consulted with the following individuals and agencies during the preparation of this
CX:

The State Historic Preservation Officer was notified per the State Protocol between the Bureau of
Land Management Wyoming State Director and the Wyoming State Historic Preservation
Officer. This entailed a notification of the finding of No Historic Properties Affected.

No other agencies, groups or individuals were contacted in the development of this project.

Decision and Rationale for Decision
It is my decision to approve the proposed action as conditioned through BLM COAs, RMMs and
applicant committed BMPs.

I have reviewed DOI-BLM-WY-P060-2021-0162-CX for the Ruby 1819-16H horizontal oil and
gas well. Conditioned through mitigation measures, I find that this action will not result in
significant impacts on the human environment pursuant to Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations
1508.27 (a) and (b) (1) through (10).

Implementation Date
EOG will initiate the proposed action within two years of the APD approval, or within four years
of the APD approval if a two-year extension is requested and approved.

Right of Protest and/or Appeal
This decision is subject to administrative review according to 43 Code of Federal Regulation
(CFR) 3165. Request for administrative review of this decision must include information
required under 43 CFR 3165.3(b) (State Director Review), including all supporting
documentation. Such a request must be filed in writing with the State Director, Bureau of Land
Management, P.O. Box 1828, Cheyenne, Wyoming 82003, no later than 20 business days after
this Decision Record is received or considered to have been received. Any party who is
adversely affected by the State Director's decision may appeal that decision to the Interior Board
of Land Appeals, as provided in 43 CFR 3165.4.

A. Background

CATEGORICAL EXCLUSION DOCUMENTATION FORMAT WHEN USING
CATEGORICAL EXCLUSIONS NOT ESTABLISHED BYSTATUTE

BLM Office: St. George

Lease/Serial Case File No: DOI-BLM-UT-CO30-2017-0046-CX

Proposed Action Title/Type: Special Recreation Permit

Location of Proposed Action: The area of the proposed action includes all of the Sand
Mountain Recreation Area (Open OHV) and all authorized routes on BLM managed lands in
Washington County that are open to the public for motorized use.

Description of Proposed Action: Authorize a Special Recreation Permit (SRP) for Southwest
Extreme LLC for the purpose of guiding clients on Utility Terrain Vehicles (UTV) on
authorized roads in the BLM St. George Field Office. The proponent anticipates 75% of their
trips would occur in the Sand Mountain Open OHV Area, with the remainder taking place on
authorized roads throughout Washington County, including the Beaver Dam Wash and Red
Cliffs National Conservation Areas.

There would be a maximum group size of twelve UTVs and a minimum group size of four
UTVs, with a minimum staff to customer ratio of 1:6. Each trip would be 3-6 hours depending
on specific tour location. All tours would occur during daylight hours throughout the year, as
weather permits. Clients and UTV's would be transported to existing trailheads or staging
areas by passenger trucks with trailers. Trips would be conducted using UTV's which carry
one driver and one passenger.

No overnight camping would be authorized on any BLM-managed public lands under this
permit. All activities would follow Tread Lightly principles. All guides will be experienced
drivers and each vehicle will carry a first aid kit. All vehicles will be equipped two-way radios
to communicate with other vehicles on the tour. In addition, each driver will have a mobile
phone. Issuance of the permit is dependent on the applicant obtaining BLM mandated minimum
insurance.

This would be a ten-year permit, valid for one year from the date of issuance and eligible for
annual renewal for an additional nine years if all the conditions are met, stipulations followed,
and post-use reports and payments made accurately and on time.

B. Land Use Plan Conformance
Land Use Plan Name: St. George Field Office, Resource Management Plan

Date Approved/Amended: March 1999
The proposed action is in conformance with the applicable LUP because it is specifically
provided for in the following LUP decision(s):

1. Chapter 2, Recreation Objectives, pages 37,38:
"Public lands in Washington County will generally remain open to most forms of outdoor
recreation, including, but not limited to: hiking, touring, camping, hunting, picnicking,
sightseeing, rock hounding, mountain biking, equestrian use, swimming, fishing,
rafting/kayaking, rock climbing, and various forms of motorized recreation."

2. Chapter 2, Off-Highway Vehicle Management, page 50, OV-09:
"BLM will continue to work with OHV sponsors and organizations to authorize competitive
events, commercial touring, and organized rides on a case-by-case basis, subject to site
specific analysis.

3. The SGFO RMP has three OHV designations that are applicable to the proposed action:
Limited to Existing Roads and Trails, Limited to Designated Roads and Trails, and Open to
Motorized Vehicle Use. All routes proposed by the applicant are located within these area
designations.

4. The BDWNCA RMP, 6.30 Recreation and Visitor Services, Rec-13, page 58:
Limit SRPs for motorized commercial and organized group recreation activities to roads and
primitive roads authorized for use by the public.

5. The RCNCA RMP, 6.31 Recreation and Visitor Services, Rec-13, page 57:
Limit SRPs for motorized commercial and organized group recreation activities to roads and
primitive roads authorized for use by the public.

C. Compliance with NEPA
The Proposed Action is categorically excluded from further documentation under the National
Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) in accordance with 516 DM 11.9, 9 (Actions Eligible for a
Categorical Exclusion): H (Recreation Management) (1}. This reference states: "Issuance of
Special Recreation Permits for day use or overnight use up to 14 consecutive nights; that impacts
not more than 3 staging area acres; and/or for recreational travel along roads. trails, or in areas
authorized in a land use plan.

Exceptions to Categorical Exclusion Documentation
The action has been reviewed to determine if any of the extraordinary circumstances (43 CFR
46.215) apply. The project would:

Extraordinary Circumstances

1. Have significant impacts on public health or safety.
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: The proposed action is identical to non-commercial recreational
ATV/UTV use that regularly occurs in this area. There is no data to suggest that
driving on existing roads in the amount and duration proposed would have a large
impact on public health or safety.

2. Have significant impacts on such natural resources and unique geographic characteristics as
historic or cultural resources; park, recreation or refuge lands; wilderness areas; wild or scenic
rivers; national natural landmarks; sole or principal drinking water aquifers; prime farmlands;
wetlands (Executive Order 11990); floodplains (Executive Order 11988); national monuments;
migratory birds; and other ecologically significant or critical areas.
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: Roughly, 75% of the proposed recreation use under this SRP would take
place in the Sand Mountain Recreation Area, which is classified as "Open" for OHV
use, meaning there are no restrictions on motorized cross-country travel. The
remainder of the proposed action would take place on existing roads currently
managed under the area designations "Limited to Existing Roads and Trails or
"Limited to Designated Roads and Trails." Because recreational UTV travel under
this permit would be restricted to specific roads and
those roads are already open to motorized use; no new or adverse impacts to sensitive
resources are anticipated to occur.

3. Have highly controversial environmental effects or involve unresolved conflicts concerning
alternative uses of available resources [NEPA section 102 (2) (E)].
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: The proposed recreation use would consist of guided UTV rides on
authorized roads that are open to the public, with two guided rides per day being
offered daily throughout the week, with a group size limit of six UTVs including
two guides. This type of action is a small percentage of the public use on these roads
and would not result in highly controversial environmental effects or create
unresolved conflicts concerning alternative uses of available resources.

4. Have highly uncertain and potentially significant environmental effects or involve unique or
unknown environmental risks.
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: There is nothing in the proposed action that would lead to significant,
unknown, or unique environmental risks.

5. Establish a precedent for future action or represent a decision in principal about future actions
with potentially significant environmental effects.
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: Since each Special Recreation Permit proposal must be evaluated
individually, authorizing a single permit does not establish a precedent for future
actions.

Extraordinary Circumstances

6. Have a direct relationship to other actions with individually insignificant but cumulatively
significant environmental effects.
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: Because of the rapidly growing population in Washington County, it is
reasonable to expect that OHV activity in general, and commercial guiding in
particular, will continue to increase. Analyzing cumulative impacts from new
proposals (both motorized and non-motorized) will continue to be done on a case-by-
case basis.

The St. George Field Office currently has six active Special Recreation Permits for
guided ATV trips. The combined use from these six permits totals less than one-half
of one percent of the recreational use on BLM lands in Washington County.
Cumulative impacts may be an issue in the future, but for now they are negligible.

7. Have significant impacts on properties listed, or eligible for listing, on the National Register
of Historic Places as determined by the bureau.
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: Continued use of designated and existing routes and trails, or use of
"open" OHV areas will have no impact on sites eligible for listing to the National
Register of Historic Places.

8. Have significant impacts on species listed, or proposed to be listed, on the List of Endangered
or Threatened Species, or have significant impacts on designated Critical Habitat for these
species.
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: No threatened, endangered, or candidate species would be impacted by
the proposed action, as all motorized travel would be restricted to existing public
roads and trails and an "open" OHV area. Because motorized travel under this permit
would be restricted to specific roads, listed native plants would not be impacted.

9. Violate a Federal law, or a State, local or tribal law or requirement imposed for the protection
of the environment.
Yes [x] No [ ] Rationale: The proposed action is in compliance with Federal, State, Tribal, and
local laws, and no activities would take place on tribal lands.

10. Have a disproportionately high and adverse effect on low income or minority populations
(Executive Order 12898).
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: The proposed action would have no effect on low income or minority
populations.

11. Limit access to and ceremonial use of Indian sacred sites on Federal lands by Indian religious
practitioners or significantly adversely affect the physical integrity of such sacred sites
(Executive Order 13007).

Extraordinary Circumstances
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: The proposed action would not limit access to, or interfere with
ceremonial use of sacred sites, nor would it adversely impact the integrity of any such
known sites.

12. Contribute to the introduction, continued existence, or spread of noxious weeds or non-native
invasive species known to occur in the area or actions that may promote the introduction,
growth, or expansion of the range of such species (Federal Noxious Weed Control Act and
Executive Order 13112).
Yes [ ] No [x] Rationale: As with any outdoor recreation activity, the proposed action may
contribute to the introduction and distribution of invasive species. Guides would be
given information materials to help them identify noxious weeds that may be
encountered, and they are and asked to report to the SGFO Recreation Planner if any
are observed. Individual trail and trailheads are inspected annually by BLM staff to
ensure that any new infestations of noxious weeds are identified and controlled.

Decision
It is my decision to implement the action described in Categorical Exclusion DOI-BLM-UT-CO30-
2017-0046-CX

Decision Rationale
I have reviewed the attached Categorical Exclusion documentation, including plan conformance,
NEPA compliance review, and extraordinary circumstances review. Based upon that
documentation, I have determined that the action is categorically excluded from further NEPA
analysis.

Administrative Remedies
This decision may be appealed to the Interior Board of Land Appeals, Office of the Secretary, in
accordance with the regulations contained in 43 CFR Part 4.

nlp = spacy.load('en_core_web_sm')
#convention_df = SampleCorpora.ConventionData2012.get_data()
short_docs = docs_pages[0:100]
corpus = CorpusFromPandas(short_docs,
                          category_col='document_type',
                          text_col='page_text',
                          nlp=nlp).build()


# create html document
html = st.produce_scattertext_explorer(corpus,
                                       category='CE',
                                       category_name='Categorical Exclusion',
                                       not_category_name='Other',
                                       width_in_pixels=1000,
                                       minimum_term_frequency=5,
                                       metadata=short_docs['document_id'])

open('../output/scattertext/ce.html', 'wb').write(html.encode('utf-8'))
print('Open ../output/scattertext/ce.html in web browser.')

Open ./simple.html in Chrome or Firefox.

title: NEPA Project Analysis: Clean Energy Environmental Reviews
NEPA Project Analysis: Clean Energy Environmental Reviews
text:
Federal environmental permitting—and, relatedly, the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA)—has often been blamed as a core contributor to delays in infrastructure deployment. However, research to date on NEPA has been hindered by federal agency data management practices: NEPA documents are scattered across numerous agency databases, often in machine-unreadable formats, and typically lack basic metadata and other identifiers. As such, researchers have had to craft bespoke subsets of NEPA data from which to glean insights—a time-consuming task that has limited the information available about NEPA’s effectiveness and paved the way for a national permitting reform conversation rife with anecdotes and cherry-picked information.
The newly released National Environmental Policy Act Text Corpus (NEPATEC) 2.0 dataset from the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory’s (PNNL’s) PermitAI project has the potential to add new, more comprehensive evidence into this conversation. PNNL has built and released a comprehensive dataset of past environmental reviews and permitting documents containing millions of pages and billions of words in machine-readable JSON format. The database contains more than 120,000 NEPA documents1 from 60,000 projects prepared by more than 60 different agencies. Each document contains metadata for (as applicable):

Lead agency
Category
Type of review
Name of project
Location
Project sponsor
Project sector
Project type (a subset of project sector)
Type of document
Document title
Agency or contractor responsible for preparing the document
Categorical exclusion category
Summary of the proposed action







Note



The National Environmental Policy Act Text Corpus (NEPATEC) 2.0 can be accessed here on huggingface.

title: NEPA Project Analysis: Clean Energy Environmental Reviews
text:
2.2 Phase 2
Phase 2 of the project is still not settled and we’ll need to scope it based on what we find and do in Phase 1. Nevertheless, these are the envisioned deliverables:

Reasons why NEPA was triggered (e.g., federal land, federal funding) for different types of projects
Determinations of significance across resource areas; factors that contribute to a determination of “significant impact”

Starting with mitigated FONSIs

Differences and similarities between NEPA reviews for fossil fuel and clean energy projects, as well as linear and non-linear projects—application of categorical exclusions, timelines, geography, etc.
Timelines for categorical exclusions, environmental assessments, and environmental impact statements, including segmentation by years (e.g., pre- and post-FRA [which set timelines for reviews], different CEQ NEPA regulations, agency, and type of project)

Timeline outliers could then be investigated through a case study approach to identify contributing factors, including whether NEPA was a cause of delay or not
May need to cross-reference with the Notice of Intents in the Federal Register using their API to get the start date

Technical support for new regulatory categorical exclusion development: identifying patterns in FONSIs

title: NEPA Project Analysis: Clean Energy Environmental Reviews
text:
4.1 Deliverable #1: Clean Energy Project Analysis
I envision making three tables to satisfy this deliverable. All of the variables for all the tables of deliverable 1 are in the metadata.






Warning



Data Challenge: Many projects have multiple tags. For example, the project named as “Coldfoot Cell Tower” in the project_title variable has two values for project_type: [‘Utilities (electricity, gas, telecommunications)’ ‘Broadband’]. While “Utilities (electricity, gas, telecommunications)” is a Clean Energy category, “Broadband” is not.


Solution approach: Create a new variable flag, called energy_type_questions. Any clean energy tag that also has a fossil fuel tag should be classified as fossil fuel.
Required new variables: - project_type_count: count of unique values for project_type - project_type_count_clean: counts unique clean energy tags
- project_type_count_fossil: counts unique fossil fuel tags

title: NEPA Project Analysis: Clean Energy Environmental Reviews
text:
5.1 Variable naming
Ensure where possible that the name of any newly created variables include a prefix in the variable name indicating the level they are. All variables at the “document” level begin with document_[varname], “project” level begin with project_[varname], etc.
Universe of possible prefixes: - project_ - project level variables - process_ - process level variables
- document_ - document level variables - pages_ - page level variables






Note



Most new variables will likely be at the “project” stage since that is the level of observation for most analyses in this project.

Appendix B - Wilderness Characteristics Assessment 
 
NEPA Document No.: DOI-BLM-AK-F030-2016-0009-EA 
 
Applicant:  GCI 
 
Serial No.: F-97066 
 
Location:  Coldfoot airport mile post 175 Dalton Highway 
 
Township/Range:  Sec. 16, T. 28 N., R. 12 W., Fairbanks Meridian, Alaska 
 
Evaluation by:  Robin Walthour 
 
Date:  February 1, 2016 
 
Proposed Action: 
 
GCI proposes to install a wireless communications tower and associated infrastructure to provide 
wireless internet service to the community of Coldfoot, Alaska. 
 
Evaluation:   
 
The basis for this evaluation is BLM Manual 6310-Conducting Wilderness Characteristics 
Inventory on BLM Lands, and BLM Manual 6320 - Considering Lands with Wilderness 
Characteristics in the BLM Land Use Planning Process, which direct offices to conduct and 
maintain inventories regarding the presence or absence of wilderness characteristics, and to 
consider identified Lands with Wilderness Characteristics (LWC) in land use plans and when 
analyzing projects under the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). 
 
Effects on wilderness characteristics on BLM lands within the Utility Corridor are evaluated 
according to the Nonwilderness Assessment, a special project approved by the BLM Director 
and conducted by the BLM along portions of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System (TAPS) corridor 
in 1980. This assessment identified lands under BLM administration that were considered 
lacking in the wilderness characteristics as defined by the Wilderness Act of 1964. The 
assessment was conducted in a manner that met the requirements of Section 603 of the Federal 
Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (FLPMA). 
 
The action being considered is located within the Sagavanirktok Segment of the Nonwilderness 
Assessment, which covered approximately 512,000 acres total in 1980. Portions of this segment 
meet the 5,000 acre minimum size. However it was determined that the Sagavanirktok Segment 
did not meet the standards for naturalness due to roads, camps, airfields, pipelines, material sites 
and associated facilities. These disturbances bisect the entire length of the segment.

2. PROPOSED ACTION AND ALTERNATIVES 
DESCRIPTION OF THE PROPOSED ACTION 
GCI is proposing to install a communication tower site on public lands near the Coldfoot airport, 
mile post 175 off the Dalton Highway within Sec. 16, T. 28 N., R. 12 W., Fairbanks Meridian, 
containing 2.29 acre.  They propose a 20 year authorization with the option of renewal to 
construct, operate, maintain, and decommission. 
 
The facility would provide UMTS (3G) wireless voice and data coverage to the community 
because there is none currently.  GCI is proposing to build an unlit, un-guyed, 80-foot-tall lattice 
tower on the parcel. A communications shelter (10 feet by 20 feet) would be secured on the same 
25-foot-by-25-foot I-beam platform as the tower. The I-beam foundation does not require 
excavation and fill, but there may be a small amount of surface leveling with a bulldozer. The 
project would also involve construction of the following: 
 
• Wireless technology cabinets housed in the communications shelter – the cabinets would 
contain 850 MHz CDMA/EVEO, 850 MHz UMTS and 700 MHz LTE, DC rectifiers and 
battery backup plant. This shelter would not require a back-up generator. 
 
• An aerial “ice bridge” between the communication shelter and the tower – the ice bridge 
would provide a structure for attaching the coaxial transmission lines and offer protection 
from falling ice. This would not involve ground disturbance because the ice bridge would 
be constructed on the I-beam ballast tower foundation. 
 
• An extension of the existing chain-link fence to enclose the communications facility. 
 
• A ground ring trenched in around the base of the ballast tower foundation at a depth of 36 
inches. 
 
• Buried electrical service and fiber optic cables from the existing GCI-operated fiber 
shelter along the ice bridge to the new site. 
 
GCI would need temporary work areas along the north, east, and south of the long-term lease 
area for the placement of the tower, shelter, and fencing. The dimensions of the temporary work 
areas would be 10 feet x 20 feet on the northwest side of lease area, 10 feet x 44 feet on the 
northeast side of lease area, and 10 feet x 30 feet on the southeast site of lease area (GCI 2015). 
GCI proposes to construct from June through July 2016. GCI would contract a construction crew 
of 3 to 4 workers to transport the material in two flatbed trucks on the Dalton Highway. The first 
truck would carry the tower sections, ballast, and I-beams and the second truck would carry the 
radio equipment and shelter. The ballast foundation would be filled with approximately 4,000 
pounds of gravel from an existing (permitted) borrow pit to stabilize the I-beams. System turn-up 
and testing would occur after construction in the fall and winter of 2016. Construction workers 
would be housed off-site at Coldfoot Camp (GCI 2015).

Coldfoot Cell Tower, F-97066

DESCRIPTION OF ALTERNATIVES ANALYZED IN DETAIL 
 
No Action Alternative 
 
Under the No Action Alternative, BLM would not grant the lease. Currently there is no wireless 
voice and data coverage in Coldfoot, and that would not change under the No Action Alternative.  
 
ALTERNATIVES CONSIDERED BUT NOT ANALYZED IN DETAIL 
 
GCI considered the collocation of its wireless facilities on the Summit Telephone tower located 
within the community of Coldfoot, Alaska. This alternative is not feasible at this time because an 
agreement could not be negotiated between GCI and Summit Telephone. 
 
3. AFFECTED ENVIRONMENT 
 
PROJECT AREA 
 
The project area is within Sec. 16, T. 28 N., R. 12 W., Fairbanks Meridian, Alaska 
 
Access/Realty 
The site is accessible via the Dalton Highway and then an existing road to the Coldfoot airport.  
The proposed site is located on land managed by BLM and is vacant, but has been disturbed by 
gravel fill and an adjacent underground utility line. 
Cultural Resources 
The potential site area has been previously disturbed by gravel fill and an adjacent underground 
utility line. No previously identified cultural resources are present within the direct area of 
potential effect (APE). The Coldfoot Historic District (WIS-00040) and Dalton Highway 
(WIS-00408) are within a half-mile visual APE.  
 
Fire Management 
The project location is within a Full Management Option fire management unit (Alaska 
Interagency Coordination Center 2015). Objectives for this management option include 
controlling all wildland fires at the smallest acreage reasonably possible by initial response 
forces without compromising firefighter safety and providing appropriate protection to identified 
uninhabited structures and property (BLM 2005). 

--- END PAGE 4 ---

--- START PAGE 5 ---
Coldfoot Cell Tower, F-97066 
 
Page 6 
 
Hazardous Waste 
The FCC requires eight (8) hours of back-up power be available for wireless site deployments. 
The typical standby power backup for wireless sites is usually accomplished by batteries.  GCI 
Facilities Engineering has specified the use of 16 valve-regulated, non-spillable lead acid 
batteries (Telcordia TEL 12-210 FG). 
 
Invasive, Non-native Plant Species 
Invasive plants are non-native aggressive plants with the potential to cause substantial damage to 
native ecosystems and/or cause substantial economic losses. Over two dozen invasive plants 
have been recorded in numerous infestations along the Dalton Highway (BLM 2013). According 
to available data, 15 invasive plant species occur in Coldfoot, AK (AKEPIC 2015). The Alaska 
Natural Heritage Program ranks plant invasiveness on a scale from 0 to 100 (100 being the most 
invasive). Three of the most notable invasive species documented in Coldfoot, Alaska are oxeye 
daisy (Leucanthemum vulgare), white sweetclover (Melilotus albus), and bird vetch (Vicia 
cracca). They have invasiveness scores of 61, 80, and 73, respectively (AKEPIC 2015). All three 
species are considered highly invasive and are identified for eradication in the Dalton 
Management Area Integrated Invasive Plant Strategic Plan (BLM 2013). 
 
Recreation 
The proposed project site is near the Dalton Highway which is popular with tour groups and 
individuals for sightseeing and for accessing recreational hunting, fishing, gold panning, hiking, 
camping, wildlife viewing, and rafting opportunities (BLM 1989, 2014). The project site is 
located near the Arctic Interagency Visitor Center in Coldfoot, Alaska. 
 
Socioeconomics 
The tower would be located near the Dalton Highway, and currently there is no existing wireless 
voice and data coverage.  
 
The community of Coldfoot was founded as a mining community, but was abandoned in 1912. 
The current population is 10, and most residents are non-native.  Fifty-nine percent of residents 
are employed, but there are no unemployment insurance claimants.  
 
Soils 
The soil at the proposed project site has been previously disturbed. 
 
Subsistence 
Subsistence is an important part of livelihood and culture, especially in rural Alaska. The Dalton 
Highway provides access to some subsistence resources such as caribou and some fish species. 
Subsistence resources are harvested in the Coldfoot area by residents and neighboring villages, 
but the proposed project site is not identified as a valuable subsistence use location.  
 
Vegetative Resources 
The project site has been previously disturbed by gravel fill and an adjacent underground utility 
line. The structure would sit above the ground on an I-beam platform. Vegetation clearing is not 
required for this project. 

--- END PAGE 5 ---

--- START PAGE 6 ---
Coldfoot Cell Tower, F-97066 
 
Page 7 
 
Visual Resources 
The project location is within the Koyukuk Drainages Scenic Quality Unit described in the 
Environmental Impact Statement for the Utility Corridor Resource Management Plan. The area 
is characterized by little visual variety and is not visually unique. The unit has been given a 
rating of Scenic Quality Class B, which is given to areas that, though pleasing to the eye, tend to 
be common throughout a landscape (BLM 1989). 
 
The site has been previously disturbed by gravel fill and an adjacent underground utility line. 
The Coldfoot Historic District (WIS-00040) and Dalton Highway (WIS-00408) are within a half-
mile visual area of potential effect. 
 
Water Quality – Surface and Ground 
The project area is permeable to precipitation and is not adjacent to waterbodies. 
 
Wildlife 
The Coldfoot area supports a variety of mammal species including brown and black bear (Ursus 
arctos, U. americanus), wolf (Canis lupus), moose (Alces americanus), caribou (Rangifer 
tarandus), lynx (Lynx canadensis), wolverine (Gulo gulo), and red fox (Vulpes vulpes). A 
multitude of bird species from seasonal migrants to year-round residents can also be found in the 
area, though there are no bird concentration areas near the proposed project site. 
 
RESOURCES CONSIDERED BUT DISMISSED FROM FURTHER CONSIDERATION 
 
Air Quality 
The cellular communication site would draw from an existing power source in Coldfoot. No 
backup generator would be required; therefore, there would be no new point source for 
emissions. The proposed action would have no adverse effect on air quality during operation. 
 
Areas of Critical Environmental Concern 
 
The facility would not be located within any designated Areas of Critical Environmental 
Concern (BLM 2011). 
 
Environmental Justice 
The population of Coldfoot is 10 (DCCED 2015). There are no minority and low-income 
populations in the project area. Coldfoot is a highway outpost where workers live temporarily. 
Therefore, there would be no disproportionate impact to minority or low-income populations. 
 
Essential Fish Habitat 
There is no Essential Fish Habitat within the project area. 
 
Farmlands, Prime and Unique 
There are no prime or unique farmlands and no farmland/soil of local importance in the project 
area. 
 

--- END PAGE 6 ---

--- START PAGE 7 ---
Coldfoot Cell Tower, F-97066 
 
Page 8 
 
Floodplains 
The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has not completed a study to determine 
flood hazard for the project location. According to the most recent flood and erosion hazard 
information available from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, there is no known flooding in 
Coldfoot, Alaska (USACE 2011). 
 
Threatened or Endangered Species 
The project location is not within the range of any proposed, candidate, threatened, or 
endangered species protected under the Endangered Species Act. 
 
Wetlands/Riparian Zones 
The project area has been mapped by the National Wetlands Inventory. No wetlands are present 
within the facility footprint (USFWS 2015). 
 
Wild and Scenic Rivers 
No Wild and Scenic Rivers are located in the project area. 
 
Wilderness 
The proposed facility location is not within a designated wilderness area. The proposed site is 
adjacent to existing developments and does not have wilderness characteristics. 
 
4. ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS 
 
DIRECT, INDIRECT, AND CUMULATIVE EFFECTS OF THE NO ACTION ALTERNATIVE 
 
Under the No Action Alternative, the Coldfoot Wireless facility would not be developed and 
there would be no impacts to access/realty, air quality, Areas of Environmental Concern, cultural 
resources, environmental justice, Essential Fish Habitat, farmlands, fire management, hazardous 
waste, invasive species, mineral resources, Native American religious concerns, recreation, soils, 
subsistence, threatened and endangered species, vegetation, visual resources, water quality, 
wetlands, Wild and Scenic Rivers, and wilderness areas. There would be no contribution to 
cumulative effects on these resources. 
 
DIRECT AND INDIRECT EFFECTS OF THE PROPOSED ACTION 
 
Access/Realty 
The proposed action would have no adverse effect on access and realty because the proposal 
does not include new roads, changes to ownership, or differ from the proposed future land use 
(BLM 1989). The project would provide additional revenue to BLM. 
 
Cultural Resources 
The proposed communication tower would be built in a previously disturbed area. There would 
be no effect to previously identified historic properties in the direct APE. 
  

--- END PAGE 7 ---

--- START PAGE 8 ---
Coldfoot Cell Tower, F-97066 
 
Page 9 
 
The proposed communication tower is expected to be visible from the Coldfoot Town Site 
(WIS-007), Coldfoot Mining Site (WIS-041), and Dalton Highway, but due to the associated 
setting and characteristics, the potential tower would have no adverse effect to these resources.  
 
Fire Management 
Human activity increases anthropogenic wildfire ignition. The proposal would not increase the 
risk of fire beyond normal risk associated with human activity and construction projects. The 
proposed activity’s environmental effect on fire management would be minimal. 
 
Hazardous Waste 
The risk of a hazardous material spill from valve-regulated, non-spillable lead acid batteries is 
very low and the effects would be localized. 
 
Invasive, Non-native Plant Species 
Ground disturbance at the facility location and use of building materials and heavy equipment 
from developed areas can increase the risk of introducing invasive species. The most common 
invasive plants in this region readily colonize disturbed substrate. The colonization and spread of 
invasive species has a negative impact on native plant and wildlife communities.  
 
The most likely source of invasive species to the project area would be the spread of invasive 
species already identified in the area and the transport of new species via vehicles working in the 
area. It would not be possible to pinpoint whether the activities associated with the tower 
construction were source of introduction. 
 
Early detection and rapid response to invasive species would help control and quickly address 
potential damage to a site if an invasive species becomes established. GCI would remove 
invasive species if they are identified by BLM on the lease area. 
 
Recreation 
The project site is adjacent to an existing developed site in Coldfoot, away from hunting, fishing, 
and mining opportunities as well as backcountry locations desired by backpackers and hikers. 
The proposed action would have no adverse effect on recreation. The increased availability of 
wireless data and cellular service would improve the safety of recreationists in the area. 
 
Socioeconomics 
During construction, there would be temporary beneficial impact to businesses in Coldfoot for 
lodging and meals for the construction workers. The tower would have a beneficial impact on the 
safety of the residents of Coldfoot and those travelling along the Dalton Highway, although 
long-term socioeconomic impacts would be negligible. 
 
Soils 
There is ground disturbance associated with leveling the ground in preparation for the 
non-ground penetrating I-beam foundation and the installation of a ground ring and fiber optic 
and power cables. The proposed tower would sit above the surface of the ground. There would  
 
 

--- END PAGE 8 ---

--- START PAGE 9 ---
Coldfoot Cell Tower, F-97066 
 
Page 10 
 
be heat-generating equipment in the shelter, but there would be fans to dissipate the heat for 
continued operation of the electronics. The adverse effects to soil, permafrost, and soil stability 
would be minimal. 
 
Subsistence 
The proposed project would not be located in a valuable subsistence harvest area and would have 
no adverse effect on subsistence. 
 
Vegetative Resources 
Although vegetation clearing is not required for the project, there could be minimal impact to 
vegetative resources from the minimal soil disturbance. There could also be negligible effects on 
sun-loving vegetation if the structure creates heavily shaded areas. 
 
Visual Resources 
The proposed site is adjacent to an existing developed site. The Coldfoot Historic District 
(WIS-00040) and Dalton Highway (WIS-00408) are within a half-mile visual area of potential 
effect. The communication tower is expected to be visible from the Coldfoot Town Site (WIS-
007), Coldfoot Mining Site (WIS-041), and Dalton Highway, but due to the associated setting 
and characteristics, the potential tower would not likely cause an adverse effect to these 
resources. 
 
Water Quality – Surface and Ground 
The project would not require the use of groundwater and the footprint of the tower would 
remain permeable. The footprint of the tower would not impact surface water because it would 
not cause additional runoff. The proposed facility footprint would have no direct impact to water 
bodies. 
 
Wildlife 
The proposed project would be located on previously disturbed land near existing human 
developments including a large utility corridor, roads, and an airstrip. The proposed project 
would occupy a small amount of space in a location that is not considered high-quality habitat 
for wildlife. The proposed tower would slightly increase the risk of avian collisions but the injury 
or mortality rate would not be high enough to affect populations. The proposed action would not 
adversely affect wildlife. 
 
CUMULATIVE EFFECTS UNDER THE PROPOSED ACTION 
 
Climate change has the potential to interact with and even exacerbate the impacts associated with 
this project including impacts to visual resources and consequences of invasive species 
introduction. Climate change may favor invasive plants if the amount and seasonal distribution 
of precipitation and seasonal temperature patterns shift in a manner conducive to invasive plant 
growth. If invasive plants are able to successfully move into areas not affected by human 
disturbances, invasive plants could alter the plant composition of ecosystems and change their 
structure and function over large landscape areas. This encroachment on native plant 
communities may happen more rapidly in the Arctic and Subarctic regions where climate change 
appears to happening at an accelerated rate compared to other regions. It is possible that invasive 

--- END PAGE 9 ---

--- START PAGE 10 ---
Coldfoot Cell Tower, F-97066 
 
Page 11 
 
plants will be better adapted than native species to the new environmental conditions resulting 
from climate change, thus outcompeting native plants and changing vegetation community 
composition and type (BLM 2013). 
 
Climate change could alter the spatial and temporal distribution of snowpack, vegetation 
communities, and surface water, all of which would impact landscape character of the project 
area. It is possible that changes in landscape character attributes, including form, line, color, and 
texture of vegetation, snowpack, and water, could increase visual contrast of the proposed 
structure. 
 
5. TRIBES, INDIVIDUALS, ORGANIZATIONS, OR AGENCIES 
CONSULTED 
 
No tribes, individuals, organizations or agencies were consulted on this proposed action.

nlp = spacy.load('en_core_web_sm')

                          category_col='document_type',
                          text_col='page_text',
                          nlp=nlp).build()


# create html document
html = st.produce_scattertext_explorer(corpus,
                                       category='EA',
                                       category_name='Environmental Assessment',
                                       not_category_name='Other',
                                       width_in_pixels=1000,
                                       minimum_term_frequency=5,
                                       metadata=short_docs['document_id'])

open('../output/scattertext/ea.html', 'wb').write(html.encode('utf-8'))
print('Open ../output/scattertext/ea.html in web browser.')

--- START PAGE 0 ---
1 
 
Determination of NEPA Adequacy (DNA) Worksheet 
 
U.S. Department of the Interior 
Bureau of Land Management 
Roseburg District 
 
OFFICE:  Roseburg District, Swiftwater Field Office 
 
CASEFILE/PROJECT NUMBER:  N/A 
 
PROPOSED ACTION TITLE/TYPE:  2016 West Entrance Trailhead Improvements 
 
LOCATION/LEGAL DESCRIPTION:  The project area is located on the North Bank Habitat 
Management Area. West ½ of the Southeast ¼ of Section 11, Township 26 South, Range 5 West, 
Willamette Meridian. 
 
DETERMINATION OF NEPA ADEQUACY (DNA):  Not all decisions require the use of a DNA.  
When used, a DNA confirms that an action is adequately analyzed in existing NEPA document(s) and is 
in conformance with the land use plan.  The DNA worksheet is not itself a NEPA document.  The signed 
conclusion in the DNA worksheet is an interim step in the BLM’s internal review process and does not 
constitute an appealable decision. 
 
A. Description of the Proposed Action 
 
The BLM would further develop the trailhead parking area at the West Entrance to the North Bank 
Habitat Management Area (NBHMA).  These developments would include: installation of a single vault 
toilet with a sealed vault, removal and replacement of the existing information kiosk, alteration of the 
existing footprint to make more efficient use of the space available through identification of parking 
spaces and ADA parking spaces, construction of ADA compliant outdoor access routes to the restroom 
and kiosk, construction of an access trail just outside of the trailhead to link the two trails served by the 
trailhead, planting of native vegetation, installation of perimeter fencing and interior fencing, installation 
of an entrance arbor and site ID sign, and removal and relocation of three hitching posts for equestrian 
use. 
 
Project Design Features 
 
• 
Equipment would be pressure washed prior to project-related activities to reduce the spread of 
noxious weed seed in accordance with direction in BLM Manual 9015- Integrated Weed 
Management.  If equipment is removed from the project area, re-cleaning and inspection would 
be required prior to re-entry onto BLM-administered lands. 
• 
Construction would be restricted during the wet season, typically October 15 through May 15.  
The wet season restriction period may be adjusted in the event of unseasonably wet weather and 
soil moisture conditions. 
 
 
 

--- END PAGE 0 ---

--- START PAGE 1 ---
2 
 
B. Land Use Plan (LUP) Conformance 
 
2001 Roseburg District North Bank Habitat Management Area/ACEC Habitat Management Plan 
and Monitoring Plan. 
 
The proposed action complies with the 2001 ROD/Habitat Management Plan and Monitoring Plan 
because it is specifically provided for in the following decision: 
 
o Issue 2. Recreational Use and Facility Development/Objective #5 Provide a range of recreational 
opportunities compatible with the management of CWTD and other Special Status Species.        
(p. 31) 
o Management Actions/West Entrance Development. The development would take place on 
approximately 1.5 acres. A single vault toilet would be established to meet public needs and 
confine wastes.  The vault toilet would be sealed to prevent water contamination by leaching. (p. 
32) 
o Description of Alternative C (preferred alternative) North Bank Habitat Management Area/ACEC 
(p. 14).  Recreational use would be accommodated through the development of new facilities 
(West Entrance, and Doc’s Landing).  Parking areas would be constructed to increase 
accessibility and decrease safety hazards to users while loading and unloading vehicles and horse 
trailers. 
 
C. Identify applicable National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) documents and other related 
documents that cover the proposed action. 
 
2001 North Bank Habitat Management Area/ACEC Environmental Impact Statement 
 
Architectural Barriers Act of 1968 – Chapter 10 – Recreation Facilities 
 
D. NEPA Adequacy Criteria 
 
1. Is the new proposed action a feature of, or essentially similar to, an alternative analyzed in the 
existing NEPA document(s)? Is the project within the same analysis area, or if the project location 
is different, are the geographic and resource conditions sufficiently similar to those analyzed in the 
existing NEPA document(s)? If there are differences, can you explain why they are not substantial? 
 
There are no differences in project location, or geographic and resource conditions that would render the 
existing analysis insufficient.  The proposed action contains features of the selected alternative analyzed 
in the NEPA document.  This included development of the West Entrance and installation of a single 
vault toilet.  The proposed action would alter the footprint of the existing staging area, however this 
would occur within the 1.5 acres identified as the project area in the selected alternative. 
 
2. Is the range of alternatives analyzed in the existing NEPA document(s) appropriate with respect 
to the new proposed action, given current environmental concerns, interests, and resource values? 
 
The alternatives considered in the North Bank Habitat Management Area/ACEC EIS (pp. 13-16) 
consisted of three alternatives; a No Action Alternative A, Alternative B, and the preferred Alternative C.  
Nothing, with respect to new information suggests that the range of alternatives were not sufficient to 
address environmental concerns, public interest, and resource values. 
 

--- END PAGE 1 ---

--- START PAGE 2 ---
3 
 
Alternative C described the accommodation of recreational use through development of new facilities, 
namely the West Entrance and Doc’s Landing, to include the construction of parking areas to increase 
accessibility and decrease safety hazards. 
 
Public interest and use in the area continues to increase and the proposed action is certainly relevant with 
respect for the need to manage recreational impacts and provide for public use.  The project would 
provide for public health and safety, manage parking, address accessibility requirements, and provide a 
facility to manage increased visitation. 
 
3. Is the existing analysis valid in light of any new information or circumstances (such as, rangeland 
health standard assessment, recent endangered species listings, and updated lists of BLM-sensitive 
species)? Can you reasonably conclude that new information and new circumstances would not 
substantially change the analysis of the new proposed action? 
 
No new information that would change the analysis with regard to the proposed action has been 
identified. 
 
4. Are the direct, indirect, and cumulative effects that would result from implementation of the new 
proposed action similar (both quantitatively and qualitatively) to those analyzed in the existing 
NEPA document? 
 
Cultural Resources 
 
Bureau of Land Management personnel conducted cultural resource surveys on July 8, 2016 (CRS 
SW1611) in accordance with Appendix A of the 2015 protocol with the State of Oregon.  No new cultural 
resources were identified during this recent survey and there are no previously identified sites in the 
project area.  This project would result in no effect to cultural properties.  The BLM has completed its 
Section 106 responsibilities under the 2012 National Programmatic Agreement and the 2015 OR 
SHPO/OR BLM Protocol.  If any cultural resources are identified during project implementation, work 
would cease in that area and a BLM archaeologist would be notified. 
 
Wildlife 
 
Direct, indirect and cumulative effects to the Columbian white-tailed deer and other sensitive 
species are unchanged from those analyzed in the North Bank HMA EIS. 
 
Botany 
 
There are no Sensitive plants in the proposed project area, therefore there are no direct, indirect or no 
cumulative effects to Sensitive plant species. 
 
Noxious Weeds 
 
Noxious weeds would be treated prior to ground disturbing activities.  Project design features 
would be followed to reduce the risk of invasion.  The project area would be monitored and 
treated as one of the Roseburg District 2016-2017 weed treatment areas.  Cleaning equipment 
prior to entry onto BLM-administered lands would be required. 
 
 
 

--- END PAGE 2 ---

--- START PAGE 3 ---
4 
 
Soils 
 
The North Bank Habitat Management Area/ACEC FEIS analyzed the direct, indirect, and cumulative 
effects of recreation facility development on soil productivity, including expanding the West Entrance 
from 0.5 to 1.5 acres as described in the new proposed action.  Short term erosion would be minor 
because construction would be limited to the dry season.  The new disturbance would permanently 
remove 1 acre from the productive land base (less than 0.02 percent of NBHMA). 
 
5. Are the public involvement and interagency review associated with existing NEPA document(s) 
adequate for the current proposed action? 
 
A mailing list was compiled consisting of individuals and organizations that requested or were sent a 
copy of Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS).  Each person or organization that attended a 
North Bank Habitat Management Area (NBHMA) open house or, submitted substantive written 
comments was also included on the mailing list. 
 
There was a sixty day public comment period for the DEIS from December 28, 1999 through February 
28, 1999, and the comment period was extended an additional 15 days until March 13 2000. 
 
The Roseburg District received 28 letters with 124 specific comments from individuals, government 
officials, and organizations.  A thirty day public review period was established on September 22, 2000 
and subsequently extended and additional fifteen days until November 6, 2000. 
 
Public involvement in the planning process for the NBHMA/ACEC was extensive and did have 
significant influence on the development of the ROD, the HMP and the Monitoring Plan 
 
Additional comments more specific to the proposed development of the West Entrance Trailhead were 
obtained at two public meetings held in May of 2016.  No new issues were identified. 
 
 
 

--- END PAGE 3 ---

--- START PAGE 4 ---

--- END PAGE 4 ---

open('./CE_docs.html', 'wb').write(html.encode('utf-8'))
print('Open ./CE_docs.html in web browser.')

title: Project Overview
text:
This document is a good reference for how to contextualize this project, the project goals and data, and to clearly understand the project deliverables and timeline.


Federal environmental permitting—and, relatedly, the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA)—has often been blamed as a core contributor to delays in infrastructure deployment. However, research to date on NEPA has been hindered by federal agency data management practices: NEPA documents are scattered across numerous agency databases, often in machine-unreadable formats, and typically lack basic metadata and other identifiers. As such, researchers have had to craft bespoke subsets of NEPA data from which to glean insights—a time-consuming task that has limited the information available about NEPA’s effectiveness and paved the way for a national permitting reform conversation rife with anecdotes and cherry-picked information.
The newly released National Environmental Policy Act Text Corpus (NEPATEC) 2.0 dataset from the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory’s (PNNL’s) PermitAI project has the potential to add new, more comprehensive evidence into this conversation. PNNL has built and released a comprehensive dataset of past environmental reviews and permitting documents containing millions of pages and billions of words in machine-readable JSON format. The database contains more than 120,000 NEPA documents1 (categorical exclusions, draft and final environmental assessments, draft and final environmental impact statements, records of decision, findings of no significant impact, and other supporting documentation) from 60,000 projects prepared by more than 60 different agencies. Each document contains metadata for (as applicable):
• Lead agency
• Category
• Type of review
• Name of project
• Location
• Project sponsor
• Project sector
• Project type (a subset of project sector)
• Type of document
• Document title
• Agency or contractor responsible for preparing the document
• Categorical exclusion category 
• Summary of the proposed action
The National Environmental Policy Act Text Corpus (NEPATEC) 2.0 can be accessed here on huggingface.

For this project, we want to create tables, figures, and maps that help us learn about the data and answer the following questions:



Data on number of clean energy projects within the dataset: number of projects broken down by technology (e.g., offshore and onshore wind, solar, geothermal, nuclear), lead agency, and location
Data on programmatic and tiered reviews: how many tiered reviews are there compared to total and are they completed faster
Data on how many clean energy projects have been categorically excluded vs. have required environmental assessments and environmental impact statements

Broken out by number of projects, generation capacity, and change over time

Data on geography/project location; whether projects are multi-state or multi-agency
Number of pages over time, including pre- and post- Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023 (FRA), which set page limit requirements
Technology-specific inquiries

Transmission lines: length of lines from project summary correlated with timelines, location, etc.
Geothermal: timelines of environmental reviews for different phases of the same project
Carbon and hydrogen pipelines (if available): length of pipelines from project summary correlated with timelines, location, etc.; compare to natural gas pipelines





Phase 2 of the project is still not settled and we’ll need to scope it based on what we find and do in Phase 1. Neverthelss, these are the envisioned deliverables:

Reasons why NEPA was triggered (e.g., federal land, federal funding) for different types of projects
Determinations of significance across resource areas; factors that contribute to a determination of “significant impact”

Starting with mitigated FONSIs

Differences and similarities between NEPA reviews for fossil fuel and clean energy projects, as well as linear and non-linear projects—application of categorical exclusions, timelines, geography, etc.
Timelines for categorical exclusions, environmental assessments, and environmental impact statements, including segmentation by years (e.g., pre- and post-FRA [which set timelines for reviews], different CEQ NEPA regulations, agency, and type of project)

Timeline outliers could then be investigated through a case study approach to identify contributing factors, including whether NEPA was a cause of delay or not
May need to cross-reference with the Notice of Intents in the Federal Register using their API to get the start date

Technical support for new regulatory categorical exclusion development: identifying patterns in FONSIs

I evision making three tables to satisfy this deliverable. All of the variables for all the tables of deliverable 1 are in the metadata.
The wrinkle here is that many projects have mutiple tags. For example, the project named as “Coldfoot Cell Tower” in the “project_title” variable has two values for project_type: [‘Utilities (electricity, gas, telecommunications)’ ‘Broadband’]. While “Utilities (electricity, gas, telecommunications)” is a Clean Energy category, “Broadband” is not. So, I’ll need to either remove the Clean Energy flag by stripping all of those unique combinations of “Utilities” and “Broadband”. For now, I want to mark it for consideration by creating a new varible flag, call it energy_type_questions. Another example has a clearer solution. The project titled “Install Oil Field Facilities and Equipment on Little 6 Tank Facility Sec 6D” in the project_type variable has the following values: ““[‘Conventional Energy Production - Land-based Oil & Gas’ ‘Utilities (electricity, gas, telecommunications)’]”. The issue here is that although it has utilities (includes gas and electric) that is a clean energy tag, it also has the fossil fuel tag of “conventional energy production - land-based oil & gas’ tag. Any clean energy tag that also has a fossil fuel tag should be classifed as fossil fuel. So, I’ll need some code to ensure any clean energy flagged project that has any fossil fuel tag is ultimately tagged as fossil fuel. Finally, I want another variable that is simply a count of the number of unique values for project_type *(call it project_type_count), another that counts the unique clean energy tags (call it project_type_count_clean), and finally one that counts unique fossil fuel tags (call it project_type_count_fossil).

title: Project Overview
text:
Federal environmental permitting—and, relatedly, the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA)—has often been blamed as a core contributor to delays in infrastructure deployment. However, research to date on NEPA has been hindered by federal agency data management practices: NEPA documents are scattered across numerous agency databases, often in machine-unreadable formats, and typically lack basic metadata and other identifiers. As such, researchers have had to craft bespoke subsets of NEPA data from which to glean insights—a time-consuming task that has limited the information available about NEPA’s effectiveness and paved the way for a national permitting reform conversation rife with anecdotes and cherry-picked information.
The newly released National Environmental Policy Act Text Corpus (NEPATEC) 2.0 dataset from the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory’s (PNNL’s) PermitAI project has the potential to add new, more comprehensive evidence into this conversation. PNNL has built and released a comprehensive dataset of past environmental reviews and permitting documents containing millions of pages and billions of words in machine-readable JSON format. The database contains more than 120,000 NEPA documents1 (categorical exclusions, draft and final environmental assessments, draft and final environmental impact statements, records of decision, findings of no significant impact, and other supporting documentation) from 60,000 projects prepared by more than 60 different agencies. Each document contains metadata for (as applicable):
• Lead agency
• Category
• Type of review
• Name of project
• Location
• Project sponsor
• Project sector
• Project type (a subset of project sector)
• Type of document
• Document title
• Agency or contractor responsible for preparing the document
• Categorical exclusion category 
• Summary of the proposed action
The National Environmental Policy Act Text Corpus (NEPATEC) 2.0 can be accessed here on huggingface.

title: Project Overview
Project Overview
text:
For this project, we want to create tables, figures, and maps that help us learn about the data and answer the following questions:



Data on number of clean energy projects within the dataset: number of projects broken down by technology (e.g., offshore and onshore wind, solar, geothermal, nuclear), lead agency, and location
Data on programmatic and tiered reviews: how many tiered reviews are there compared to total and are they completed faster
Data on how many clean energy projects have been categorically excluded vs. have required environmental assessments and environmental impact statements

Broken out by number of projects, generation capacity, and change over time

Data on geography/project location; whether projects are multi-state or multi-agency
Number of pages over time, including pre- and post- Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023 (FRA), which set page limit requirements
Technology-specific inquiries

Transmission lines: length of lines from project summary correlated with timelines, location, etc.
Geothermal: timelines of environmental reviews for different phases of the same project
Carbon and hydrogen pipelines (if available): length of pipelines from project summary correlated with timelines, location, etc.; compare to natural gas pipelines





Phase 2 of the project is still not settled and we’ll need to scope it based on what we find and do in Phase 1. Neverthelss, these are the envisioned deliverables:

Reasons why NEPA was triggered (e.g., federal land, federal funding) for different types of projects
Determinations of significance across resource areas; factors that contribute to a determination of “significant impact”

Starting with mitigated FONSIs

Differences and similarities between NEPA reviews for fossil fuel and clean energy projects, as well as linear and non-linear projects—application of categorical exclusions, timelines, geography, etc.
Timelines for categorical exclusions, environmental assessments, and environmental impact statements, including segmentation by years (e.g., pre- and post-FRA [which set timelines for reviews], different CEQ NEPA regulations, agency, and type of project)

Timeline outliers could then be investigated through a case study approach to identify contributing factors, including whether NEPA was a cause of delay or not
May need to cross-reference with the Notice of Intents in the Federal Register using their API to get the start date

Technical support for new regulatory categorical exclusion development: identifying patterns in FONSIs
